text:
Fifth Avenue, west side, from 40th to 42nd Street, showing old reservoir. This was demolished in 1902 to be replaced by the New York Public Library. Bristol Hotel, later converted into an office building, stands at right background.

About 1897.

Elmendorf, Photographer;
copyrighted by Ewing Galloway.

Fifth Avenue, west side, north from 40th Street, showing portion of old reservoir and Bristol Hotel.
1897.
Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

Fifth Avenue, west side, 42nd to 40th Street, showing old reservoir. Site now occupied by New York Public Library. 1898.

Brown Brothers, Photographer, copyright.

Old reservoir, Fifth Avenue, west side, 40th to 42nd Streets, being drained for demolition.
The view is along the Fifth Avenue wall, with the Hotel Bristol and 42nd Street buildings in the background. Some idea of the tremendous thickness of the walls may be gained by remembering that the outer walls also slope outward.
The New York Public Library was constructed on this site.
1901-1902.

Fifth Avenue, east side, from 40th to 42nd Streets. 1907.
Brown Brothers, Photographers.

S.E. corner of Fifth Avenue and 40th Street, on present site of Arnold Constable Department Store.
May 1909.
Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

President John Bigelow (age 94) and his daughter Grace arriving for the dedication of N.Y.P.L.
23 May 1911

Dedication of N.Y.P.L.
23 May 1911

President John Bigelow (age 94) and his daughter Grace arriving for the dedication of N.Y.P.L.
23 May 1911

Dedication of N.Y.P.L.
23 May 1911

Fifth Avenue, west side, north from 40th Street (left), showing prominently the N. Y. P. L. to the south of 42nd Street. Above same is the towering office building, No. 500 Fifth Avenue (under construction). Views 1 and 2 are photograohed from atop the Arnold WWonstable building at the S. E. corner of 40th Street. No. 3 is westward on 41st Street to show the main entrance to the
LLibrary.
Views 1,2 August 4, 1930
P. L. Sperr
View 3 SSeptember 28, 1913
M. Vaxer

Fifth Avenue; at the S. W. corner of West 42nd Street, showing details of the New York Public Library plaza at this point. Buildings in the background are on the east side of the Avenue extending from 41st (left) to 39th (right) St's. 40th Street is just behind the feminine figure shown.

About 1914

New York Edison Co., photo.
Gift of Gress (21 Nov. 1935)

Fifth Avenue, north from 40th Street. At centre is the New York Public Library and above it is the Bristol office building, formerly the Bristol Hotel.
Note Republican National Committee campaign streamer for Charles E. Hughes, presidential candidate defeated by Woodrow Wilson.

Fall 1916.

Ng.741

ROOM 300

ROOM 300

315G

New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue, west side, from 40th to 42nd Streets.
Bristol Building at extreme right.
About 1917.

text:
Demolition work, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, to make way for the American Radiator Building. 36 and 46 West 40th Street are also shown.

June 5, 1923.

Peyser & Patzig.

Excavating for the American Radiator Building, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

July 10, 1923.

Peyser & Patzig.

Foundation work on the American Radiator Building, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

July 23, 1923.

Peyser & Patzig.

Foundation work on the American Radiator Building, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

July 23, 1923.

Peyser & Patzig.

Foundation work on the American Radiator Building, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

August 6, 1923.

Peyser & Patzig.

Foundation work on the American Radiator Building, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

August 6, 1923.

Peyser & Patzig.

Foundation work and shoring on the American Radiator Building, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

August 20, 1923.

Peyser & Patzig.

Foundation work and shoring for the American Radiator Building, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

August 20, 1923.

Peyser & Patzig.

Start of construction work on the American Radiator Building, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

September 6, 1923.

Peyser & Patzig.

Start of construction work on the American Radiator Building, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

September 6, 1923.

Peyser & Patzig.

Construction work on the American Radiator Building, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. 36 and 40-56 West 40th Street are also shown. 56 West 40th Street at the right, is the Republican Club. September 24, 1923.

Peyser & Patzig.

Construction work on the American Radiator Building, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

October 4, 1923.

Peyser & Patzig.

Construction work on the American Radiator Building, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. The view is west along the south side of 40th Street from 32 West 40th Street. The building at the left is the Engineers' Club. The first building above the row of four-story buildings is the Republican Club.

October 18, 1923.

Peyser & Patzig.

Construction work on the American Radiator Building, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. 36 and 40-56 West 40th Street are also shown. 56 West 40th Street at the right, is the Republican Club. September 24, 1923.

Peyser & Patzig.

Construction work on the American Radiator Building, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. 54-46 and 36 to 2 West 40th Street are also shown. At the right is the Republican Club; in the centre, to the left of the American Radiator Building, is the Engineers' Club; and the next building beyond the row of brownstones is the New York Club.
November 18, 1923.

Peyser & Patzig.

Construction of the American Radiator Building, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. 50-46 and 36-28 West 40th Street are also shown. At the left is the Engineers' Club.

December 3, 1923.

Peyser & Patzig.

The American Radiator Building as it nears completion, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. The picture also shows 58-46 and 36-24 West 40th Street. At the right is the Republican Club, while just to the left of the American Radiator Building, separated from it by a single four-story building, is the Engineers' Club.

December 18, 1923.

Peyser & Patzig.

Fifth Avenue, at the N. E. corner of 40th Street opposite the Public Library.

1924

32, 36, 40, 46, 48-52 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, with part of Bryant Park in the foreground. No. 40 is the newly completed American Radiator Building.
November, 1924.

P. L. Sperr.

The American Radiator Building as it nears completion, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. The picture also shows 58-46 and 36 to 6 West 40th Street. At the right is the Republican Club; just to the left of centre is the Engineers' Club; while at the left, seen between the lamp post and tree, with a second tree obscuring its face, is the New York Club.

January 4, 1924.

Peyser & Patzig.

The American Radiator Building as it nears completion, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, also showing 58-46 and 36 to 4 West 40th Street. At the right is the Republican Club; to the left of centre is the Engineers' Club; while below the latter, and separated from it by a row of brownstones, is the New York Club.

January 14, 1924.

Peyser & Patzig.

The American Radiator Building nearing completion, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, showing also 28-36 and 46-56 West 40th Street. At the left is the Engineers' Club, with its flag at half-staff in honor of former President Woodrow Wilson, who has just died. At the right, seen through the bare branches of a tree, is the Republican Club.

February 9, 1924.

Peyser & Patzig.

The American Radiator Building nearly completed, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. Also shown is 28-36 and 46-58 West 40th Street. The Engineers' Club is at the left, while the Republican Club is seen through the branches of the tree in the right foreground.
February 27, 1924.

Peyser & Patzig.

The American Radiator Building nearly completed, 38-44 West 40th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, showing also 56-46 and 36-18 West 40th Street. The Republican Club is at the right and the New York Club at the left. Between the two is the Engineers' Club.

March 6, 1924.

Peyser & Patzig.

The New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue And Forty-Second Street
Copyright by Underwood & Underwood, N.Y.
Feb. 1925

New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue, west side, from 42nd to 40th Street.

February 10, 1927.
New York Edison Company Collection.

New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue, west side, from 40th to 42nd Streets.
February 10, 1927.
New York Edison Company Collection.

Fifth Avenue, west side, from 40th to 42nd Street. The New York Public Library occupies this site and is photographed from the rear. Fifth Avenue is beyond same. W. 40th Street is on the right and 42nd Street on the left. Surrounding same are the towering structures comprising the Grand Central-42nd Street outline. Note in View 1, two of these units under construction. They are the Chanin and No. 10 E. 40th Street buildings.

August 24, 1928
April 27, 1929
February 28, 1930

P. L. Sperr

1928 No other information

130-2 W. 42nd Street (Bush Terminal Building), between 6th Avenue and Broadway showing a general view eastward from atop this 29 storied office building. 42nd Street is to the left and 40th Street on the right, skirting the N. Y. P. L. on Fifth Avenue. In the background, from right to left, are the outstanding, No. 10 E. 40th Street, Chanin, and Lefcourt-National Buildings. View 2 is photographed from the Wurlitzer Building, a lower structure that is slightly east of the above vantage point. Note the new skyscrapers in this area. In the same order, they are the Lefcourt-Colonial (later No. 40 E. 41st Street), Lincoln, and Chrysler Buildings. The latter is under construction. No. 500 Fifth Ave. is in the same stage. This will overshadow its neighbor, the Salmon Tower.

View 1: March 18, 1929
View 2: May 7, 1930

P. L. Sperr

130-2 W. 42nd Street (Bush Terminal Building), between 6th Avenue and Broadway showing a general view eastward from atop this 29 storied office building. 42nd Street is to the left and 40th Street on the right, skirting the N. Y. P. L. on Fifth Avenue. In the background, from right to left, are the outstanding, No. 10 E. 40th Street, Chanin, and Lefcourt-National Buildings. View 2 is photographed from the Wurlitzer Building, a lower structure that is slightly east of the above vantage point. Note the new skyscrapers in this area. In the same order, they are the Lefcourt-Colonial (later No. 40 E. 41st Street), Lincoln, and Chrysler Buildings. The latter is under construction. No. 500 Fifth Ave. is in the same stage. This will overshadow its neighbor, the Salmon Tower.

View 1: March 18, 1929
View 2: May 7, 1930

P. L. Sperr

Rear of Public Library, Fifth Avenue, west side, from 40th to 42nd Streets, from Bryant Park. Tall buildings, left to right, are: Chrysler, Lincoln, Lefcourt Colonial, and 10 E. 40th Street. About 1930.

Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

A general view, west from Fifth Ave., east side, between 41st and 42nd streets, showing at the right,500 Fifth Ave., (N.W. corner of 42nd St), the Paramount Building in the background (with clock) 43rd St., and Seventh Ave). and the Hudson River. Also shown in the foreground is the New York Public Library (main branch, 5th Ave., and 42nd St). and Bryant Park.
1931
Wurts Brothers.

Fifth Avenue, west side, from 40th to 42nd Streets, showing details of the new roofing at the N. Y. P. L. building. This was performed by the W. P. A. through the assistance of the City of New York. The new metal covering is "Monel" or a similar alloy and replaced a copper sheathing. The four views here are northward towards a background formed by W. 42nd Street and Fifth Avenue. Note the glimpse of the latter thoroughfare on the right of one of these photos.

April 7, 1937
Views 1,2,3,4

W. P. A. photo
Five Boroughs Project

No. 2 shows the side wall and windows that will be utilized for an entrance. The regular arched doorway is on the extreme right, but does not appear in these scenes.

title: Police activities - Mounted police.

text:
Fifth Avenue (left), at the S.W. corner of West 42nd Street (right), showing the Central Building of the New York Public Library, occupying the west side of the Ave. from 40th to 42nd Streets. At the rear of same and extending to Sixth Ave., is Bryant Park, completing what was formerly the site of the Reservoir. This photograph, taken at 7 P.M., shows a southwestward view towards structures that surround this open area in Manhattan's heart. On the left, and partially cropped by the top margin is the huge Empire State Building at 34th Street.

February 7, 1938.

Mr. Nathan Schwartz.
New York Public Library.

Fifth Ave., west side, north from West 40th to 42nd Streets, showing the Central Building of the New York Public Library photographed at dusk (6:30 P.M.). The skyscrapers on the right are, the huge No. 500 Fifth Ave. Building and the Salmon Towers.

March 17, 1938.

Mr. Nathan Schwartz.
New York Public Library.

Fifth Avenue, west side, south from W. 42nd Street, (right) showing a night view of the New York Public Library and surrounding buildings. To the left, decapitated, is the Empire State Building at 34th Street.

Mr. Nathan Schwartz
New York Public Library

Fall, 1938

Fifth Avenue, west side, from 41st to 42nd Street; showing the main entrance to the New York Public Library, the north wing and the Esplanade as viewed from the side walk curb on the Avenue. To the right is a portion of the No. 500 - Fifth Avenue Building, located at the N.W. corner of W. 42nd Street.

February 1939

Mr. Nathan Schwartz
New York Public Library

Fifth Avenue, west side, at 41st Street, showing the New York Public Library and one of its watchful lions.

Winter 1939

Alexander Alland

text:
Fifth Avenue, west side, from 4oth to 42nd Streets, showing the N. Y. P. L. esplanade and main entrance. At the right is a portion of the towering office structure at the N. W. corner of 42nd Street. This is known as the No. 500 Fifth Ave. Bldg.

February 1940

George D. Chinn

Fifth Avenue, west side, from 40th to 42nd Streets, showing the front of the New York Public Library the morning after a snowstorm.

The view is northward on the esplanade frontage, with 42nd Street and its towering 500-Fifth Avenue Building on the right.

February 16, 1940

Nathan Schwartz
New York Public Library
Photostat Division

Fifth Avenue, west side, from West 40th to 42nd Street's, showing the removal of the flag pole and base at the south end of the plaza to the front of the N.Y.P.L. View 1 is southward, with the Library on the right, and Fifth Avenue buildings to the left. The latter comprise the 40th to 39th Street frontage. In the center is the Brooks Bros. Bldg. at the S.W. corner of 40th Street. View 2 is northward and includes the skyscraper, No. 500 Fifth Avenue.

text:
Tablet from old Croton Aqueduct.
When the New York Public Library was built, this tablet was mounted in the main floor hall-way, but was destroyed when the mezzanine was built.

Bristol Building at extreme right.
New York Public Library at centre. Dimly in background is Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
